Posts.Content: Hi all New here. As you see from the subject line, I have a Stereotactic Biopsy scheduled for this coming Tuesday - 8/14. I've been doing lots of reading and think I may want to get another opinion before I do it. One of the things that disturbs me the most, aside from all the post-Biopsy horror stories of pain, infection and the titanium marker moving or migrating, is what I read on the thread below: LINK REMOVED AS PER FORUM POLICY It frightens me that the very Biopsy that tells us whether or not our suspect breast "lump" is malignant or benign also has the potential to metastasize the cancer via the biopsy's needle track later on. Has anyone else heard this before? BTW: This is my first experience with any sort of potential cancer, including breast. Thank you for reading. NSJ
Posts.Title: Stereotactic Biopsy Question

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Prometheus I'll throw in my two cents as a radiation therapist. Yes seeding through tumor biopsy or excision is a possibility, but imagine if you never had the excision/biopsy you'd be way worse off. It's better for doctors to know what they're dealing with so they can come up with a proper treatment approach. If they do the biopsy and the tumor is benign you're in the clear no worries. If they do the biopsy and the tumor is malignant than they know they must take appropriate action. For breast cancer a combination chemo and radiation therapy approach is common. For radiation therapy the whole breast is treated for a period of time to eliminate the initial cancer and any microscopic cancer that might be in the breast, after the initial phase of the treatment a "boost" is given. The boost is basically extra radiation given to the tumor site and scar from the tumor removal, the goal of the "boost" is to kill any possible remaining cancer that may have seeded during the tumor removal. So in a nutshell from how I see it as a radiation therapist. Yes, you may be at risk for seeding during a biopsy but it's better to know you have cancer and get the proper treatment than to refuse a biopsy for fear of seeding and let your potential cancer go untreated. Breast treatments account for seeding from the biopsy and always give more than enough chemo/radiation to eliminate all possibility of a second incidence. So the original post does bring some important information to light but at the same time if you have or may have breast cancer don't be alarmed. This may be news to the general public but to the team that is treating you it is old news and you will receive the proper course of treatment. Up above Prometheus wrote "biopsy or excision". Does "excision" mean lumpectomy??? Anyone?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Blu I've had many biopsies. The first was over 30 years ago and luckily all have been benign. I have a marker that was implanted 10 years ago and haven't had any issues with it I also never had any problems with any of my biopsies afterwards. Originally Posted by Blu I've had many biopsies. The first was over 30 years ago and luckily all have been benign. I have a marker that was implanted 10 years ago and haven't had any issues with it I also never had any problems with any of my biopsies afterwards. Thanks so much for responding, Blu. I'm so glad to read that. An Article I read states concerns by researchers where they fear the stereotactical procedure may spread (or seed) the cancer, causing something called "needle track metastasis." There was a study done in 2004 by a doctor named Hansen called the "Manipulation of The Primary Breast Tumor and The Incidence of Sentinel Node Metastases From Invasive Breast Cancer," that was published in the American Medical Association's prestigious journal, Archives of Surgery, revealing that patients undergoing fine needle biopsies were 50% more likely to have micrometastases spread to the sentinel lymph node than those patients having the entire tumor removed for biopsy. The implication of this discovery is that a woman without lymph node involvement, who would have been staged at a low level, now will be staged higher, her disease considered more advanced, and more aggressive treatment might be recommended. Has anyone read or heard of this study regarding Stereotactic Biopsy? NSJ

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Didee I have not read all of this but there may be some information here. http://www.cancerforums.net/threads/...immune-Disease Thank Didee! I scanned through it and see no mention of "needle track metastasis" caused by having a stereotactical biopsy. The study also said that over the years, several researchers have voiced serious reservations about routine needle biopsies (i.e., stereotactical), but they were mostly ignored by their colleagues. Hansen's research team cited their predecessors, and the research path leads back several decades. It's hard to understand why The Archives of Surgery study, which embodies all of these reservations about needle biopsies, didn't make the front page of the New York Times. Then Cancer authority, Ralph Moss, commented in his February 6th, 2005 Moss Reports Newsletter: "Imagine the outrage these patients will feel when they learn that many of these sentinel node metastases were caused not by the natural progression of their disease but directly by the actions of well-intentioned (but ill informed) doctors. Imagine, further, what will happen when patients find out that questions have been raised about the safety and advisability of needle biopsies for a number of years by some of the finest minds in oncology. Imagine the disruption of the smooth functioning of the "cancer industry" when patients start demanding less invasive ways of diagnosing tumors. And imagine the class action lawsuits."
